Award.AwardTitle: Optimal Offshore Wind Power Generation Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches

The objective of this proposal is to create a design process for offshore wind generation systems. The design process will explore a variety of advanced technologies for the electric machinery as well as the power conversion and electrical connection to shore power. The approach for this research project is to apply optimal design to a notional offshore wind farm considering a myriad of promising new technologies so as to achieve high performance, low weight and scalability.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this proposal comes about from development of novel approaches to design highly efficient, compact and reliable offshore wind power generation systems. The main components of the system should be designed carefully and optimally. The goal of this proposal is to overcome the challenges regarding the design of megawatt level generators, power converters and transmission system and finally grid integration.

Broader Impacts

Offshore wind power production has taken root in Europe and is planned for future implementation in the U.S. This specific form of energy production looks promising in terms of the amount of wind energy that can be harvested, the economic impact of "green" jobs, and the strength in diversifying the U.S. energy portfolio. The proposed research would further knowledge of existing and potential technologies of offshore wind generation and assist quicker adoption of these technologies. The principal investigator will flow down scientific findings from this research directly into courses she is teaching in renewable energy which, due to the long-term social component, tend to attract minorities and females students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wind energy is the second fastest growing renewable energy source for power generation after solar photovoltaic. 52 GW of new generation was added in 2017, reaching a total installed capacity of 539 GW globally1.  Traditionally, land-based wind farms have higher prominence over offshore wind farms due to lower cost. However, offshore wind farms have the advantages of higher energy potential, and reduced human and environmental impact. These advantages coupled with the falling bid prices have resulted in significant growth of offshore wind energy by 30% in 20171.

To reduce the system cost and improve the performance of offshore wind farms, current industry and research trends as understood from our literature survey are as follows:

  • Increase in individual wind turbine (WT) capacities to reduce the cost, reaching up to 10 MW per WT;
  • Migration from doubly-fed induction generators to direct-drive permanent-magnet (PM) generators to eliminate the mechanical gearbox, reduce weight and improve efficiency;
  • Full-scale ac-dc and dc-dc power conversion systems with high-frequency isolation to reduce size, weight and achieve better controllability;
  • Modular converter architectures to reduce cost, component ratings and improve scalability, and reliability;
  • Energy storage integration to meet supply volatility and increase capacity factor; and
  • Migration towards medium-voltage dc (MVDC) and high-voltage dc (HVDC) collection and transmission systems from traditional ac systems to improve controllability, efficiency, reliability and reduce cost.

Keeping up with the current trends, our research contributions for this project are as follows:

  • A new flux-switching permanent-magnet (FSPM) machine with high torque density, robustness and fault-tolerance has been developed for offshore wind applications. Machine design was optimized using 2D and 3D finite-element-analysis simulations. The proposed machine achieves comparable performance with traditional PM synchronous generators with additional advantages such as: robust rotor structure, easy thermal management and zero unbalanced magnetic forces.
  • New current-fed dc-dc boost converter topologies with soft-switching and high-frequency isolation have been developed, to step-up and interface the generator-rectified dc voltage to MV/HV dc output. Soft-switching results in reduced switching losses, leading to improved efficiency and power density of converters. High-frequency switching in kHz range allows ultra-compact transformers. Proposed configurations are modular and based on full-bridge and three-phase topologies. Converters with output-parallel and output-series configurations suitable for both MV and HV output are presented respectively. Achieved outcomes with proposed converters include: 50% reduction in voltage stress across converter components such as switches, inductor and transformer windings, 50% reduction in input current ripple reducing input inductor requirement, reduction in component count, fault-detection and fault-tolerant operation, etc. Converter analysis, modeling, control, and performance comparisons have been demonstrated using simulation tools. Experimental validation is also presented on scaled-down hardware prototypes.
  • Using proposed converters as building blocks, series-connected WT architecture was presented, where each WT has MVDC output and multiple WTs are connected in series to form the HVDC transmission link. Eliminating the offshore energy collection platform results in significant cost savings, which can reduce the overall system cost. At the receiving-end of HVDC link, two systems were investigated: 1. Series-connected high-frequency step-down dc-dc conversion unit similar to the sending-end followed by a dc-ac inverter, and 2. Series-connected multi-terminal voltage source converter (VSC) based systems for direct ac grid connection. Sending-end, receiving-end converter control and system-level simulations are presented to validate the proposed ideas. 

 

1.   REN21, 2018, Renewables 2018 Global Status Report (Paris: REN21 Secretariat).
